title: GoAccess not showing 'Tx.' Amount
body:
Hi all

I'm testing GoAccess to read Wasabi bucket logs that supposedly are equal to AWS S3 logs so I'm using the "--log-format awss3" option. Everything works great, but the one thing missing is the bandwidth amount the actual data I want to check ðŸ˜„ 

Is there anything specific I should check as to why it won't show the bandwidth?

Here are a few example lines:

```
Record format: [BucketOwner Bucket Time RemoteIP Requester RequestId Operation Key Request-URI HttpStatus ErrorCode BytesSent ObjectSize TotalTime Turn-Around
546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 bucket-name [06/Aug/2024:16:37:48 +0000] 109.50.101.102 546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 BE95910000C4743B:A REST.HEAD.OBJECT preseed%2Fubuntu.seed "HEAD /preseed/ubuntu.seed" 404 NoSuchKey - 0 6 0 "" "MSP360/Wasabi Explorer/6.2.2" -
546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 bucket-name [06/Aug/2024:16:37:48 +0000] 109.50.101.102 546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 78DF800008286EE7:A REST.HEAD.OBJECT EFI%2Fboot%2Fbootx64.efi "HEAD /EFI/boot/bootx64.efi" 404 NoSuchKey - 0 4 4 "" "MSP360/Wasabi Explorer/6.2.2" -
546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 bucket-name [06/Aug/2024:16:37:48 +0000] 109.50.101.102 546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 1F45D000085389F8:A REST.PUT.OBJECT preseed%2Fubuntu.seed "PUT /preseed/ubuntu.seed" 200 - - 460 109 0 "" "MSP360/Wasabi Explorer/6.2.2" -
546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 bucket-name [06/Aug/2024:16:37:49 +0000] 109.50.101.102 546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 FBCCB00003E9E20E:A REST.HEAD.OBJECT boot%2Fgrub%2Fx86_64-efi%2Fadler32.mod "HEAD /boot/grub/x86_64-efi/adler32.mod" 404 NoSuchKey - 0 3 0 "" "MSP360/Wasabi Explorer/6.2.2" -
546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 bucket-name [06/Aug/2024:16:37:49 +0000] 109.50.101.102 546858E6E300000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000DC170 71D310000F00E8B2:A REST.PUT.OBJECT boot%2Fgrub%2Fx86_64-efi%2Fadler32.mod "PUT /boot/grub/x86_64-efi/adler32.mod" 200 - - 1952 68 30 "" "MSP360/Wasabi Explorer/6.2.2" -
```
author: pjgerardo

comments.body:
So, is `BytesSent` equivalent to 'bandwidth'? It looks like theyâ€™re all showing as 0 in that sample log.

This should do it (assumes certain fields, e.g., TotalTime).

    goaccess access.log --log-format='%^ %v [%d:%t %^] %h %^"%m %U" %s %e %b %^ %L %^"%^" "%u"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T --http-protocol=no

If it's the `objectsize`, you could try:

    goaccess access.log --log-format='%^ %v [%d:%t %^] %h %^"%m %U" %s %e %^ %b %L %^"%^" "%u"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T --http-protocol=no
Gonna close this for now, but feel free to reopen if you need to.

title: Incremental processing of piped data
body:
I use filtering log via `grep` and piping data to `goaccess` because of small memory on server  (as i wrote here #2665)

command looks like this:
```
grep -E -f - radiopunctum.cz.access.log | goaccess --config-file /etc/goaccess.conf --output report.html --persist --restore --db-path db-data
```

it works well for first run, when i run it second time (after 24hours) output report is not updated with new data

i found in man this note:

>  Important
Since piped data works based on a timestamp and there's no way to determine the inode nor the last line parsed, some issues could arise. For instance, a piped log could have multiple consecutive lines with the same timestamp (even at the second level), so it's likely to end up with duplicates entries. However, as a best practice and a reasonable assumption is that in most cases, for incremental log processing, users will parse data directly with goaccess instead of piping it through.

is that mean that i cannot use my command above for updating data? 
how would you recommend modifying the command above to make the update work?
will saving `grep` output to file solve this?
author: tyctor

comments.body: it seems that i looked to wrong numbers, now it is updating, so everything is OK :+1:

It's great to hear that you've resolved it. The piping shouldn't hinder data updates. The note you referred to is mainly for people to understand that piping data and restoring from disk could potentially introduce duplicate records with the exact timestamp. Let me know if you have any other questions.

hmm, command is working but something is weird and i don't undersand what
maybe you can help me to explain this

setup is: above shell command is run by python script, it use `Popen` from python `subprocess` module in `django` management command, it periodically runs command in 15min interval in `while True` loop
and what i am observing i cant explain:

- when i run django command manually from shell, report is updating

- when i run django command and let it update report in that `while True` loop, report data are not updating, only date of report is updated

- when i run django command from cron, report data are not updating, only date of report is updated

all db files has chaged last modified, so something happend, but data updates only when i run command manually from shell (ssh connected server)

OMG, solved ... I forgot to put dash as last symbol into command line
and it seems that when i run it manually dash is not needed

anyway, it is working now like a charm

title: "Static Requests" panel empty in 1.8.1
body:
I just upgraded my Goaccess container from 1.8 to 1.8.1 and suddenly the static requests panel stays empty. All other panels load fine and show proper data, the websocket connection is also working fine. The console in Firefox shows no errors. The goaccess server is also not logging anything.

I run Goaccess via Docker, making it ingest an nginx log:

```yaml
version: "3.8"

services:
  goaccess:
    image: allinurl/goaccess:1.8.1
    restart: unless-stopped
    command:
      - --agent-list
      - --real-time-html
      - --config-file=/zoidberg/etc/goaccess/mysite.conf
      - --db-path=/zoidberg/var/goaccess/mysite
      - --persist
    volumes:
      - "/etc/goaccess:/zoidberg/etc/goaccess:ro"
      - "/srv/www:/zoidberg/srv/www"
      - "/var/log:/zoidberg/var/log"
      - "/var/goaccess:/zoidberg/var/goaccess"
    networks:
      - nginx_nginx
    logging:
      driver: "json-file"
      options:
        max-size: "1m"
        max-file: "10"
```

And my config is

```
# example goaccess conf file for gopanel
# edit site1 values and change title to suit
html-report-title mysite

# the logs you want to process
log-format COMBINED
log-file /zoidberg/var/log/nginx/mysite-access.log

# the location you will host from
output-format /zoidberg/srv/www/stats.mysite/index.html
ws-url stats.mysite:443/wss

# other options as you prefer
#ignore-crawlers true
#hide-referrer example.com
```
author: xrstf

comments.body:
I presume this is related to #2576 and the changelog entry

> Prevent setting default static files when no static-file options are defined in config file. 

I did not expect such a breaking change in a patch release. ^^

Valid observation. I concur regarding the impactful change. I should have taken that into account earlier. Still, I think #2576 does a good job balancing flexibility and simplicity. Feel free to give me a heads-up if you spot any problems with that specific change.

title: Response time format (seconds vs. milliseconds)
body:
Thanks a bunch for sharing GoAccess. It a great tool which just works! I have a question about response time analysis that I hope someone can help me out solving. 

I have a custom log file with the following format:

`2023-12-20T08:17:21Z GET 200 260.403 ms 2048 kB 15.36% /list/default`

I have tried to parse it using the following command:

`goaccess --datetime-format='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ' --log-format='%x %m %s %T %h %^ %^ %^%r' --no-ip-validation`.

I end up with something like this:

```
 Hits     h% Vis.      v% Avg. T.S. Cum. T.S. Max. T.S. Mtd     Proto    Data
 ---- ------ ---- ------- --------- --------- --------- ------- -------- ----
   17 45.95%    1 100.00%   4.46 mn   1.26 hr   7.46 mn GET     ---      % /list/default
```

As I understand the output Average T.S. (time spent?) is reported in minutes but that does not make sense combined with the response time reported in milliseconds. 

I know that `%T` corresponds to "The time taken to serve the request, in seconds with milliseconds resolution" but if I switch to `%L` (The time taken to serve the request, in milliseconds as a decimal number) I get `0.00 us` in all time columns. I also tried with. `%n` for good measure but that also yielded `0.00 us`.

I wonder if it has to do with `.` or `,` is used as decimal separator? but I could not spot any way to configure this in the documentation.

Notes: Since the log does not have any host name information I (mis)use the `ms` element as the hostname combined with `--no-ip-validation`.
author: kasperg

comments.body:
Great question! It appears that you can accomplish this by utilizing `%L` when splitting the `.` to capture the whole number.

    goaccess access.log --datetime-format='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ' --log-format='%x %m %s %L.%^ %h %b %^ %^ %U' --no-ip-validation

Let me know if that helps
That works like a charm! Really appreciate the help.

title: Rewind persisted db to remove corrupted entries
body: I managed to run my background analytics job twice at the same time and now I have a bunch of data for "hits" that appears to be double counted (there is an obvious segment of the chart where the "hits" line is twice the height of before and after). I was wondering if it's possible for me to rewind the persisted database to some date so I can re-run goaccess over the original logfiles to reprocess that data? Thanks so much!
author: chr15m

comments.body: Unfortunately you can't rewind the database. All the data gets aggregated as it's inserted. Do you still have the logs available?
Ok thanks, I'll rebuild using the original logs.

title: bash: /usr/bin/find: Argument list too long
body:
I have about 27000 logs file and need to parse them in one time.
every time i run this command 
goaccess  /home/goaccess/part/2/*.log --log-format='%^ %dT%t.%^ %v %h:%^ %^ %^ %T %^ %s %^ %^ %b "%r" "%u" %k %K %^' -o /var/www/html/index.html --date-format=%Y-%m-%d --time-format=%T

it says 
bash: /usr/bin/find: Argument list too long

please help me....need to do this urgently.
author: CloudShubham

comments.body:
You probably want to cat them all and pipe that to goaccess. e.g.,

    cat /home/goaccess/part/2/*.log | goaccess - --log-format='%^ %dT%t.%^ %v %h:%^ %^ %^ %T %^ %s %^ %^ %b "%r" "%u" %k %K %^' -o /var/www/html/index.html --date-format=%Y-%m-%d --time-format=%T

> You probably want to cat them all and pipe that to goaccess. e.g.,
> 
> ```
> cat /home/goaccess/part/2/*.log | goaccess - --log-format='%^ %dT%t.%^ %v %h:%^ %^ %^ %T %^ %s %^ %^ %b "%r" "%u" %k %K %^' -o /var/www/html/index.html --date-format=%Y-%m-%d --time-format=%T
> ```

Ok i will try that

Hi.

If you use `BASH` Shell must be work. But, `CSH` possibly NOT.
In Last case, do you need simulate behavior through a loop.
For example:

```
# in BASH script

FILES4BLOCK=1000
find /home/goaccess/part/2/ -type f -iname '*.log' > list-of-files.txt
FILESTOTAL=$(cat list-of-files.txt | wc -l)
ii=1
while [ ${ii} -lt ${FILESTOTAL} ]
do
      cat $(tail -n +${ii} list-of-files.txt | head -${FILES4BLOCK})
      (( ii += ${FILES4BLOCK} ))
done |  \
goaccess ...
```

It will loop with 1000 files at each `CAT` run until end of list.
Closing this. Feel free to reopen if necessary.

title: Gandi.net - simplehosting - parsing access.log
body:
Hello, I'm using the simplehosting solution from gandi.net.
I'm in trouble because they use a custom template for access.log : 
```LogFormat "%V %a %l %u %t (%T s) \"%r\" %>s %b \"%{Referer}i\" \"%{User-agent}i\"" vhost_paas```
eg : 
`domain.fr 43.130.00.000 - - [12/Apr/2023:15:07:52 +0000] (0 s) "GET /files/ HTTP/1.1" 404 196 "binance.com" "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/90.0.4430.85 Safari/537.36"`

So I tried
`goaccess /Volumes/XX/access.log --log-format="%V %a %l %u %t (%T s) "%r" %>s %b "%{Referer}i" "%{User-agent}i"" vhost_paas --datetime-format=%d/%b/%Y:%H:%M:%S %z`
that give me `Token '[10/Apr/2023:06:59:08' doesn't match specifier '%t` I tried many options with --date and --time from previous issues without success.

I'm on a mac, using french locale and installed goaccess with brew.

Thanks in advance.
author: RolandTi

comments.body:
Please try:

    goaccess access.log --log-format='%v %h %^[%d:%t %^] (%T %^) "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T

You may need to use:

    LC_TIME="en_US.UTF-8" goaccess log --log-format='%v %h %^[%d:%t %^] (%T %^) "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T
Hello allinurl ! You're right with the LC_TIME, thank you very much !
@RolandTi Glad that did the job! Let me know if you have any other questions

author: shadeekam

comments.body:
Hello, sorry for the late reply. This looks like an error log? goaccess works best with an access log. A simple `awk` | `uniq` may help:

```
#!/bin/bash

# Define the log file
LOG_FILE=/path/to/logfile.log

# Extract the fields using awk and count unique occurrences
echo "Counting unique occurrences of fields in $LOG_FILE ..."
echo "-------------------------------------------------------"

# Count unique occurrences of field 1 (timestamp)
echo "Count of unique timestamps:"
awk '{print $1}' $LOG_FILE | sort -u | wc -l

# Count unique occurrences of field 5 (log level)
echo "Count of unique log levels:"
awk '{print $5}' $LOG_FILE | sort -u | wc -l

# Count unique occurrences of field 8 (log message)
echo "Count of unique log messages:"
awk '{print $8}' $LOG_FILE | sort -u | wc -l
```
Thank you very much.. I'll look into awq

One thing, would it be possible to have it automatically parse log files in a defined folder?

That way log rotating will not mess-up parsing and you would not have to change the config every time you add a new log from a system. you would to have to tell what ever system it may be, to output logs to that folder in what ever format you have configured I GoAccess.

comments.body:
Thank you! As far as folders, you should be able to run something like:

    goaccess /path/folder/*.log --log-format=COMBINED -o /path/output/report.html

Let me know if that answers your question.

title: No input data was provided nor there's data to restore when running in a python srcipt
body:
When I run `cat logs/access.log | /usr/bin/goaccess --log-format='%h [%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u" %T' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T -o html` from shell, it works. 

But when I run from python , it fails with error: `GoAccess - version 1.7 - Jan 1 2023 03:16:59 Config file: /etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf Fatal error has occurred Error occurred at: src/goaccess.c - initializer - 1471 No input data was provided nor there's data to restore.`
```py
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import subprocess


cmd = '''cat logs/access.log | /usr/bin/goaccess --log-format='%h [%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u" %T' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T -o html
'''
def runcmd(command):
    ret = subprocess.run(command,shell=True,stdout=subprocess.PIPE,stderr=subprocess.PIPE,encoding="utf-8",timeout=10)
    if ret.returncode == 0:
        return ret.stdout
    return ret.stderr

print(runcmd(cmd))

```
author: xiangnanscu

comments.body:
Did you find the issue? Sounds like you passing `-` to goaccess should solve your issue.

    /usr/bin/goaccess - --log-format='%h [%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u" %T' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T -o html
yes it is. Thanks

body:
Hello,

I'm trying to analyze a uwsgi log file.

Goaccess' log format is quite cryptic... could anybody help me get the right formats for this file? I'd be very grateful!

I tried the formats suggested in #386, but at least the dates are completely wrong.

Here are a couple of lines from the file:

```
[pid: 3492075|app: 0|req: 4282/169885] 54.36.148.22 () {38 vars in 549 bytes} [Mon Nov 28 06:41:16 2022] GET /actus/61476774cb7d6ede781a9b4a => generated 15747 bytes in 24 msecs (HTTP/2.0 200) 2 headers in 82 bytes (1 switches on core 0)
[pid: 3492075|app: 0|req: 4283/169886] 54.36.148.231 () {38 vars in 709 bytes} [Mon Nov 28 06:41:25 2022] GET /resize/uploaded/pictures/4b8ea68f9f6a44c882b7fe0a9e75e621.jpg?v=YUdm_A&w=1024&s=b'Qut9-GQTlTM55BX1xNnZKrGqskA' => generated 122538 bytes in 9 msecs via sendfile() (HTTP/2.0 200) 6 headers in 242 bytes (0 switches on core 0)
[pid: 3492075|app: 0|req: 4284/169887] 185.191.171.21 () {40 vars in 539 bytes} [Mon Nov 28 06:43:31 2022] GET /robots.txt => generated 12511 bytes in 1 msecs (HTTP/1.1 404) 2 headers in 89 bytes (1 switches on core 0)
[pid: 3492075|app: 0|req: 4285/169888] 185.191.171.21 () {40 vars in 677 bytes} [Mon Nov 28 06:43:31 2022] GET /agenda/61b1e344f02ed2de108bc54a => generated 238040 bytes in 206 msecs (HTTP/1.1 200) 2 headers in 83 bytes (2 switches on core 0)
```
author: amiguet

comments.body:
Sorry for the delay. This should do it:

    goaccess access.log --log-format='%^] %h %^[%x] %m %U %^(%H %s) %^' --datetime-format='%a %b %d %H:%M:%S %Y' --date-spec=min --ignore-panel=OS --ignore-panel=BROWSERS --ignore-panel=REFERRING_SITES

That seems to work, many thanks! :-)

I had to prefix the command with

```
LANG="en_US.UTF-8"
```

as suggested in #2415 because my local locale (!) doesn't match the locale of the log file.

But other than that it works great. Thanks!
Glad to hear you got it working!

title: Token '09/Jan/2001' doesn't match specifier '%d'
body:
Hi,

Date format is `%d/%b/%Y` and still getting error `Token '09/Jan/2001' doesn't match specifier '%d'`

Any suggestions what should be the right full log format with dates and times? ðŸ¤” 

I'm running app with defaults `goaccess access.log` and then choosing `NCSA Combined Log Format` with defaults:
- `log format` - `%h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u"`
- `date format` - `%d/%b/%Y`
- `time format` - `%H:%M:%S`

Sample log lines:

```
10.0.0.0 - - [09/Jan/2001:00:07:51 +0000] "GET /endpoint HTTP/1.1" 418 0 "-" "User-agent"
10.0.0.0 - - [09/Jan/2001:00:08:02 +0000] "GET /endpoint HTTP/1.1" 418 0 "-" "User-agent"
```

Looks like Combined Log Format, but the `%h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u"` doesn't work ðŸ˜ž 

Any suggestions? ðŸ™
author: flashlabs

comments.body:
Usually this is due to conflicts between your log and your locale. i.e., log has English dates (e.g., Feb/Apr/Oct) while machine has a different locale. Please try running goaccess as:

    LANG="en_US.UTF-8" bash -c 'goaccess access.log --log-format=COMBINED'

Or

    LC_TIME="en_US.UTF-8" goaccess access.log --log-format=COMBINED
Ofc you are right and both of your solutions work! Thanks!
Glad that solved the issue :) Feel free to reopen it as needed.

title: debug-file flag
body:
Hi,

I'm running something similar to below, not sure if I'm doing something wrong here but the debug file gets created as "--debug-file=goaccess.debug" rather than "goaccess.debug". The invalid requests file gets created correctly.

goaccess -l --debug-file=goaccess.debug --invalid-requests=goaccess.invalid --no-global-config --ping-interval=15 --config-file=goaccess.conf

Thanks!
author: xavier-hernandez

comments.body:
Looks like you are passing `-l` + `--debug-file` which are the same. I'd do one or the other one but not both:

    goaccess --debug-file=goaccess.debug --invalid-requests=goaccess.invalid --no-global-config --ping-interval=15 --config-file=goaccess.conf
Thanks for letting me know. It should be fixed now :)

title: Stats when rewriting log file on remote sync
body:
Hi,

I am doing real time syncing files from our web server to goaccess server. And we have lots of servers

For now, I did for 4 servers, so all the log files from those servers are available in goaccess server and I am running goaccess by mentioning all the log files. But I am getting wrong data 

How do I confirm?

1) BW in the server is not matching with the goaccess stats
2) We also measure stats via stats plugin provided by the server and it is not matching with goaccess

3) I see 150M+ hits in goacces stats where as I went to each log files and counted the lines

a) 7518
b) 1692
c) 1678
d) 68134

Not sure why gostats gives wrong value. Where it went wrong?
author: rsidhaarth

comments.body: Sounds like a log format issue. Please see your other post #2350. Are you parse only one of those logs, e.g., 1692 and see if you get the same number of lines? Otherwise, feel free to attach that log here and I can take a look.

You did not understand the issue, maybe I did not explain it well.

I just ran this

wc -l squid.log

12760 squid.log

And then I made goaccess to parse only that log, every thing is configured in .conf file

So I ran goaccess and immediately I see only those lines 12760, but after few seconds, it started increasing to large quantity.

Because, the log file is being synced from remote host to this server via lsyncd. So goaccess is reading again differently.

It sounds like it's overwriting the file each time you synced the log. You need a way to forward your logs to central log server as opposed to copying it over and over again. or you could try mounting it via sshfs and have goaccess read those logs from the mount.
Closing this. Feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: Please help with my Apache Log format (including request times)
body:
Hello,

My Apache LogFormat was the following:

    LogFormat "%{X-Forwarded-For}i %l %u %t \"%r\"  %>s %b \"%{Referer}i\" \"%{User-Agent}i\"" varnish
    LogFormat "%{X-Forwarded-For}i %h %l %u %t \"%r\"  %s %b \"%{Referer}i\" \"%{User-agent}i\"" combined-forwarded
    CustomLog /var/log/httpd/access.log varnish
    ErrorLog /var/log/httpd/error.log 

With this, I am able to generate report with goaccess without problems, but I am not fetching the response times so the report is being generated without the AVG. TS / CUM. T.S / MAX. T.S that i need.

I have tried adding the '%D' param in the LogFormat like this:

    LogFormat "%{X-Forwarded-For}i %l %u %t %D \"%r\"  %>s %b \"%{Referer}i\" \"%{User-Agent}i\"" varnish
    LogFormat "%{X-Forwarded-For}i %h %l %u %t %D \"%r\"  %s %b \"%{Referer}i\" \"%{User-agent}i\"" combined-forwarded
    CustomLog /var/log/httpd/access.log varnish
    ErrorLog /var/log/httpd/error.log 

In the /var/log/httpd/access.log I can see this info is now being received, for example:

10.10.49.139 - - [23/May/2022:10:15:17 +0200] **18598** "GET /xxxxx/animations.min.css HTTP/1.1"  200 18468 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:100.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/100.0"

10.10.49.139 - - [23/May/2022:10:15:17 +0200] **13073** "GET /xxxxxdist/scripts/main.js HTTP/1.1"  200 55574 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:100.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/100.0"

I am not able to generate a valid Goaccess report that includes the (AVG. TS / CUM. T.S / MAX. T.S) - i understand now this values is being fetched with the '%D'.

Please anybody can help me with the log-format parsing for my case? It will be high appreciated.

Thanks in advance for help.

comments.body:
Please try the following, it should do the job:

    goaccess access.log --log-format='%h %^[%d:%t %^] %D "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T

Hello,

==24275== Token '' doesn't match specifier '%s'

title: [Question] Why does there need to be separate databases for --date-spec?
body:
I assumed that I could use the same database when accessing --date-spec=hr when I already created a database with --date-spec=date. I assumed that all the data for --date-spec=hr would be there in the database from --date-spec=date. However, when I try that it does not work and only shows the results from --date-spec=date instead of hourly. I am using output of json.

It does work if I create 2 separate databases.

Is this by design?
I have another feature request for --date-spec=min. I am also curious about that.
I need to generate a report for all three (date, hr, min) and I am trying to find the most efficient way possible.

Thanks
author: ggedde

comments.body:
Good question. When using `--date-spec=<hr|min>`, that data is parsed and stored into the db as specified by that option. In your case, you probably want to create three reports, however, it depends exactly on what you are looking for. If you are mostly interested on the visitors panel metrics, then you could generate it using `--date-spec=min` and then you can post-process the JSON file and strip the date as needed.

I'm working on #117 as we speak, I'm thinking this would give you more flexibility as you will be able to filter by date ranges and correlate all that data.

Thanks @allinurl, creating three different reports and databases is not that big of an issue. So I'll probably keep moving forward with that.

As far as doing the post process I don't think that'll work for my reports. I am only focused on the unique visitors. If hour 1 has four unique visitors and hour 2 has 3 unique visitors, there's no real way to know for sure how many unique visitors there were for hours 1 and 2 as it could be anything between 4 and 7. This is also the same issue between hours and days and that's why I can't just process off of the hours report to get the days numbers. Let me know if that makes sense or if there is something that I am missing.

Thanks
Makes sense. You will need to have goaccess process the log at the granular level.

I think it's Common Log Format with Virtual Host, but the prefix is throwing me off. Log is rendered like so:

```log
Dec 16 00:00:00 prod.site.com auth-apache-access: 99.99.99.999 9999 - [16/Dec/2021:00:00:00 +0000] "POST /api/user/ HTTP/1.1" 200 471 "-" "Python-urllib/3.7"
```

How do I take this into account for the custom format?

Thanks for your time.
author: rdhar-test

comments.body:
Hi @rdhar-tc 

It is seems more NCSA Combined with Virtual Host (VCOMBINED).
Maybe you can try this, at `goaccess.conf`:

`time-format %H:%M:%S`
`date-format %d/%b/%Y`
`log-format %^ %^ %^ %v %^ %h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u"`

or `--time-format="..."` `--date-format="..."`  `--log-format="..."`, at command-line.

Thank you, @0bi-w6n-K3nobi, I really appreciate your response. That works a treat!

As an added (low-fi) workaround, I also had success with `cut -c17- access.log` to trim the fixed length prefix before piping the output as `--log-format=VCOMMON`.

Thanks once again for your time.

title: `--html-prefs='{"theme":"dark gray"}'` does not work, maybe?
body:
Hello everyone,

weâ€™re having problems with starting `goaccess` with the `dark gray` theme applied by default â€¦

`goaccess /var/log/nginx/access.log -o /var/www/monitoring/index.html --log-format=COMBINED --real-time-html --html-prefs='{"theme":"dark gray"}' --ssl-cert=/etc/letsencrypt/live/<domain>/fullchain.pem --ssl-key=/etc/letsencrypt/live/<domain>/privkey.pem --daemon`

We tried `--html-prefs='{"theme":"dark gray"}'`, `--html-prefs='{"theme":"dark-gray"}'`, `--html-prefs='{"theme":"dark_gray"}'`, `--html-prefs='{"theme":"darkgray"}'`, and `--html-prefs='{"theme":"darkGray"}'` without sucess.

Any advice, please?
author: fooness

comments.body:
Hi @fooness 

The correct form is `{"theme":"dark_gray"}`.
However, the browser can cache your last choice at any report or real-time report that you already seen.
So, do you need clean cache or create a new profile [at browser] to be sure that your selection was obeyed.

I hope that could help you.
Thank you!

title: Ask for help for parsing Weblogic log
body:
Hi, i want to try to use GoAccess to parse Weblogic log with the following format:

2021-09-30	11:07:21	GET	/foo/bar/test.jsp	200	xx.xx.xx.xx	-	-
2021-09-30	11:07:22	GET	/foo/bar/	200	xx.xx.xx.xx	"yy.yy.yy.yy"	"Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko"

It is tab separated, xx.xx.xx.xx is the proxy ip and "yy.yy.yy.yy" is the client ip. 
For "VISITOR HOSTNAMES AND IPS", if "yy.yy.yy.yy" is -, use xx.xx.xx.xx, if "yy.yy.yy.yy" has value, use yy.yy.yy.yy.

When I try to use:
goaccess test.log* --log-format='%d\t%t\t%m\t%U\t%s\t%h\t~h{"\t}\t"%u"' --date-format='%Y-%m-%d' --time-format='%H:%M:%S'

It will return error:

Parsed 1 linesproducing the following errors:
Token already set for '%h' specifier.
Format Errors - Verify your log/date/time format

Would you please help? Thank you.
author: Fatsi321

comments.body:
Hi @Fatsi321

First , I have two questions:
* Maybe the first line have quotation marks in the last fields? i.e `... xx.xx.xx.xx` **`"-"` `"-"`**
   A pattern is needed on all lines/requests.
* Is there really `TABS` between the fields? Wouldn't it be simple `SPACE`?

Hi @allinurl

I'm having a little trouble doing this parse...
I am not able to adjust the `~h` field correctly and so it is swallowing the others as `%u`.

Yeah! I'm using last version _1.5.2_.

> Hi @Fatsi321
> 
> First , I have two questions:
> 
> * Maybe the first line have quotation marks in the last fields? i.e `... xx.xx.xx.xx` **`"-"` `"-"`**
>   A pattern is needed on all lines/requests.
> * Is there really `TABS` between the fields? Wouldn't it be simple `SPACE`?

Thanks for replying.
I tried to manual edit the log with "" in the last fields, but seems not working.
Yes they the tabs, I double checked in Notepad++ too.
Thank you.
I think using %h and ~h in the same filter is not supported. I would replace %h with %^ (ignore field).
Sorry for the late reply. Can you please attach a file with actual access log lines (a few lines is fine)? It's hard to determine the spacing without an actual file to work with. Thanks

title: Error Config file: No config file used
body:
I'm unable to set my config file for GoAccess permanently.

If I run `goaccess access.log -c` and chose the first option everything goes smoothly and I can access the log. If I want to create a real-time webpage, I got the error on the title.

My GoAccess conf file is in _/etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf_ and my log is in _/var/log/apache2/access.log_

Ho can I create the dynamic page in my public HTML folder _/var/www/html/report.html_ ?
author: NicoCaldo

comments.body:
Please try setting your config file under `~/.goaccessrc` and setting your options in there (no equal sign within the config file).

Then you should be able to run it as:

    # goaccess /var/log/apache2/access.log -o /var/www/html/report.html

or 

    # goaccess /var/log/apache2/access.log -p ~/.goaccessrc -o /var/www/html/report.html

It seems that this command worked

```
# goaccess /var/log/apache2/access.log -p /etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf -o /var/www/html/report.html --real-time-html
```

title: Having a hard time with persistent storage
body:
Hey,
I'm running into some issues with persistent storage and live monitoring.
I want to constantly transfer data from my log file to the persistent storage location but also keep already saved logs.
But somehow every time I launch goaccess with
`--real-time-html --persist --restore`
it doesn't constantly save to my storage location.
It isn't quite clear to me whether it saves periodically or not at all.
I couldn't really find anything regarding this in the doc.
I'm honestly really confused rn.
I managed to load all of my old log files using `zcat /var/log/apache2/access.log.*.gz | goaccess -a
`
and then `goaccess --persist`
If you could help me out by telling me wether it will save to my data location would be great.
Also does running it daemonized have an impact on it?
Edit: config file is setup correctly with a persistent storage location.
author: Lennart01

comments.body:
I'd run it once as:

    # zcat access.log.*.gz | goaccess access.log.1 - -o report.html --log-format=COMBINED --persist

and then just keep adding data to the db as:

    # goaccess access.log -o report.html --log-format=COMBINED --persist --restore

Every time the log rotates, access.log would be the newest and you would just keep adding the new data on top it. 

Also, before you try that, I'd make sure to the delete current runs that you may have persisted before, e.g.,

    # rm -rf /tmp/*.db

Give it a shot and let me know how it goes.

yeah about that.
my initial question would be whether if I run it with --real-time-html and ---persist will it save only once on execution or also down the line?
and thanks if this doesn't work I will definitely try that.

If `--real-time-html --persist` doesnt autosave I would just run it once with `--realtime-html` and implement a log rotate hook as described in the guide by Arnaud Rebillout.
I kinda want a live monitoring with live data but also long-term data storage.
Ive now managed to get my old logs pulled with the method you described.
Im now running it with `goaccess /var/log/apache2/access.log -o /var/www/html/downloads/report.html --persist --restore --log-format=COMBINED --real-time-html`

You should be fine, `--real-time-html` doesn't affect anything since a complete parse is done, the only difference is that when using real-time, the response to the browser is much lighter than a full blown report. The data is persisted upon exiting/closing goaccess. e.g., SIGINT - `Ctrl+C`

so If I run it with `--real-time-html` from now on it will autosave on termination.
Thank you very much that saved me a lot of hastle.

Happy to help :)

Closing this, feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: Issue with %h specifier with custom log
body:
I have the following log
`[16/Jul/2021:06:58:18 +0000] - 200 200 - GET https api.jirubizu.cc "/docs" [Client 141.101.99.151] [Length 504] [Gzip 1.98] [Sent-to 192.168.1.153] "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:90.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/90.0" "-"
`
And this is my log format
`log_format [%d:%t %^] - %s %^ - %m  %v "%U" [Client %h] [Length %b] [Gzip %^] "%u" "%R"
time-format %T
date-format %d/%b/%Y
`

However I keep getting this error
`Token 'lient 141.101.99.151' doesn't match specifier '%h'`
author: Jirubizu

comments.body:
Hi @Jirubizu 

Almost is OK here! But you did forgot to ignore `https` word.
Try this:
`log_format [%d:%t %^] - %s %^ - %m`**`^%`**`%v "%U" [Client %h] [Length %b] [Gzip %^] "%u" "%R"`

Notes:
Are you sure it will always be this "minus" character? At the excerpt above: `... +0000] - 200 200 - ...`
If `NOT` then change `log_format` to `... %^] %^ %s %^ %^ %m ...`

This should do it:

    goaccess log --log-format='[%d:%t %^] - %s %^ - %m %^ %v "%U" [Client %h] [Length %b] %^"%u" "%R"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T
Closing this. Feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: X-Forwarded-For field not parsing
body:
goaccess 1.5.1 macos 11.4

I am not able to convince goaccess about the X-Forwarded-For field in my logs.  There is nothing special about it:

```
test.log:
x.x.x.x - - [15/Jul/2021:14:18:11 +0200] "GET / HTTP/1.1" 200 33900 "-" "-" "y.y.y.y.y" 0.137 TLSv1.2
```

```
goaccess --log-format='%h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u" ~h{," } %T %^' test.log
```

This always shows `x.x.x.x` in the "Visitor Hostnames and IPs" (not `y.y.y.y`)
author: minusf

comments.body: so `%h` and `~h` are exclusive?  is this mentioned somewhere in the man page?

Part of it was in the man page, under the specifiers section. I expanded this to hosts as well.

> Important
> If multiple time served specifiers or hosts are used at the same time, the first option specified in the format string will take priority over the other specifiers.

ok, that helps.  but i am still confused becasue `%h != ~h`, one is `host`, the other is `x-forwarded-for`, they might be both just ip numbers but they are specifying 2 entirely different things..  i see that `%x` is already taken but maybe `~X` would be a less confusing specifier for it?
Good point, the reason it uses `~h` is that whatever is extracted either through `~h` or `%h`, that's what it's going to be put in the hosts panel.
ok, that also kind of makes sense :}  if some of this could be captured in the man page, i think that would be great! i'll close this now if it's fine with you. thank you for the help.

title: OpenLiteSpeed Common log format not being detected
body:
Hello and thanks for reading my issue :D 

I've been experiencing some trouble reading my virtual host access log for anylisis and I've scrapped the whole web in search of answers but I could not find a forum for this tool.

I changed my virtual host log format from `NCSA extended/combined log format` to `Common Log Format (CLF)` since my results didn't show any unique visitors, 404's, time distributions or even http status codes.  I was using this command: `sudo goaccess vhost.access_log --log-format='"%h %l %u [%d:%T] "%r" %>s %b "%{Referer}i" "%{User-Agent}i" "%{Host}i""' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T` When i used NCSA ext/com.

Now, when trying to parse Common Log Format things get weird, the OpenLiteSpeed documentation shows the exact same expression as the apache documentation which is this one: `"%h %l %u %t \"%r\" %>s %b"` (Note the `\` used to escape quotations).

But when trying to load the new common log format file I get this error:

```
Parsed 10 lines producing the following errors:

Token 'example.com' doesn't match specifier '%h'
Token 'example.com' doesn't match specifier '%h'
```
My log file looks like this (CLF):

```
"example.com 000.000.000.00 - - [21/May/2021:02:36:14 +0000] "GET / HTTP/2" 200 10540"
```

I'm using this command: `sudo goaccess vhost.access_log --log-format='"%h %l %u %t "%r" %>s %b"' --date-format=%d/%b/:Y --time-format=%T` which doesn't work.

What am I doing wrong here? I've checked the documentation and tried a few variants in the log format but no success yet :( is there any way to solve the missing results issue? or am I just wrong in the log format?

Thanks in advance for your response :)
author: ghost

comments.body:
Hello,

Assuming no quotes around each line, then this should work:

    sudo goaccess vhost.access_log --log-format='%v %h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T

with quotes:

    sudo goaccess vhost.access_log --log-format='"%v %h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T

The first command worked like a charm. I'm assuming I missed the `%v` parameter and the `%^` as well. Thanks a lot for helping me solve this issue :) , I think I should have read the documentation again to see those two.

Glad that solved the issue :)

Feel free to reopen it if needed.

My server logs changed (without prior notice, idk if this came with an OLS update) and now look like this:

`"<ip-addr> - - [12/Jun/2021:06:10:42 +0000] "GET /route/ HTTP/1.1" 301 0"`

I've tried modifying the commands above but I get stuck at parsing the date with this error :(
`Token '-' doesn't match specifier '%h'`

Should I include the `-` 's in the log format?

Fixed it. Here is the solution if someone else comes around the same problem:
`--log-format='"%h - - %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T`

title: Token '' doesn't match specifier '%h'
body:
So, I am having this issue when trying out goaccess. I am trying to read the standard linux .log files.

Token '' doesn't match specifier '%h'

Logs are like this one:

Jan 25 23:06:39 gopwcd kernel: [    0.000000] KERNEL supported cpus:
author: gopwcd

comments.body: Hello - goaccess works very well with access logs. You will need a consistent pattern to parse other logs.

title: Log Format
body:
Hi i want to ask to help with configure log format.
My apache config is set to
log-format %{%Y-%m-%d %T}t.%{msec_frac}t %{%z}t %v:%p [%{c}a|%a] [%{X-Forwarded-For}i] %X \"%u\" \"%r\" %>s %Ib %Ob %{us}Tus
author: vidanil89

comments.body: Please post a few lines from your access.log. Thanks

Hi @vidanil89.

Let's go on...
Try this, in `goaccess.conf`:

`date-format %Y-%m-%d`
`time-format %H:%M:%S`
`log-format %d %t.%^ %^ %v:%^ [%^|%h] %^"%R" "%r" %s %^ %bb %Dus`

or in command-line:
`--date-format='...'` `--time-format='...'` `--log-format='...'`

**notes:**
* `seconds.fraction` is not yet implemented, so I ignored the fractional part;
* it is more common to use the `%B` format instead of `%O`, however `%O` will better express the Tx. Amount.;
* additionally you can ignore the unused panels:
  `--ignore-panel=OS`, `--ignore-panel=BROWSERS` and `--ignore-panel=REQUESTS_STATIC`;

I hope it helped.

title: Default value of keep-last
body:
Hello, 
what is the default value of the **keep-last** parameter, 
used in conjunction with **persist = true**?
7 days?
infinite?

Thank's for your job!
author: danilort

comments.body:
Hi @danilort 

Just see into your conf `/etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf`.
If it is commented then it is `zero` == `infinite`, i.e. without any limitation.
Do a simple test, with a few requests for each day, and you will be sure of it.
And this parameter is independent of the flag `persit`.

I hope I've helped.

Great. 
Thanks

As @0bi-w6n-K3nobi zero is default which is equal to infinity regardless of persist. 

If you have any other questions, feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: How to make "Encryption Settings" panel workï¼Ÿ
body:
In goaccess manual page, there have an "Encryption Settings" panel, it said: this panel shows the SSL/TLS protocol used along the Cipher Suites. This panel is not enabled unless %K is given within the log-format variable.

but I don't know how to add %Kï¼Œplease help, I want to check TLS & ciphers (%K & %k)

I'm using ubuntu 20.10, goaccess 1.4.3, nginx 1.19.5

I make goaccess as service, and use real-time-html, everything is work

```
root@ubuntu:/etc/nginx# service goaccess status
â— goaccess.service - Goaccess Web log report.
     Loaded: loaded (/etc/systemd/system/goaccess.service; enabled; vendor preset: enabled)
     Active: active (running) since Sat 2020-12-19 23:20:32 HKT; 14min ago
   Main PID: 302423 (goaccessreport)
      Tasks: 4 (limit: 971)
     CGroup: /system.slice/goaccess.service
             â”œâ”€302423 /bin/bash /usr/local/bin/goaccessreport
             â””â”€302425 /usr/local/bin/goaccess /var/log/nginx/access.log - -o /var/www/html/index.html --ws-url=wss://xxx.xxx.com --ssl-cert=/etc/cert>

Dec 19 23:20:32 ubuntu systemd[1]: Started Goaccess Web log report..
```

 I just want to add %K & %k, make "Encryption Settings" panel work, here is the goaccess.service

```
[Unit]
Description=Goaccess Web log report.
After=network.target
StartLimitIntervalSec=0

[Service]
Type=simple
User=root
Group=root
Restart=always
RestartSec=1800
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/goaccessreport
StandardInput=tty
StandardOutput=tty
StandardError=tty
TTYPath=/dev/tty7

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```

/usr/local/bin/goaccessreport :

```
#!/bin/bash
zcat -f /var/log/nginx/*access.log.* | /usr/local/bin/goaccess /var/log/nginx/*access.log - -o /var/www/html/index.html --ws-url=wss://xxx.xxx.com --ssl-cert=/etc/cert/ecc384.crt --ssl-key=/etc/cert/ecc384.key --log-format=COMBINED --real-time-html
```

here is my nginx.conf log setting:

```
log_format proxy '$proxy_protocol_addr - $remote_user [$time_local] '
                     '$ssl_protocol/$ssl_cipher '
                     '"$request" $status $body_bytes_sent '
                     '"$http_referer" "$http_user_agent"';
```

and here is the real log in /var/log/nginx/access.log

```
111.224.7.4 - - [19/Dec/2020:23:10:18 +0800] TLSv1.2/ECDHE-ECDSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256 "GET /1 HTTP/1.1" 404 188 "-" "Mozilla/4.054101423 Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 9.0; Windows NT 6.1)"
```

In my case, how to make "Encryption settings" panel work?

Sorry, I'm stupid, I really don't understand the manual page "CUSTOM LOG/DATE FORMAT" section.

thanks for help first.
author: cwyin7788

comments.body:
This should do it:

    goaccess access.log --log-format='%h %^[%d:%t %^] %K/%k "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T

> This should do it:
> 
> ```
> goaccess access.log --log-format='%h %^[%d:%t %^] %K/%k "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T
> ```

Thank you very much for your quick reply, it works.

title: Goaccess Error occurred at: src/parser.c - read_log - 2730
body:
Good day!
I am getting an error when executing the command:

$ zcat /var/log/nginx/access.log.*.gz | goaccess /var/log/nginx/access.log --log-format=COMBINED

GoAccess - version 1.4 - Oct 19 2020 14:08:20
Config file: /usr/local/etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf

Fatal error has occurred
Error occurred at: src/parser.c - read_log - 2730
Unable to open the specified log file. Permission denied

I work with DJANGO and I have failed to implement real-time statistics export.
Therefore, I implemented the export of the report through a script, but when the script is executed, the statistics are displayed for one day.  And I need to display statistics since the start of the web server.
author: andrgayday

comments.body:
Hi.
I hope that message is clear. Or not? **`"...  Permission denied"`**
Your user need permission for read the `LOG`.

I should too add character **`-`** for read from `PIPE`. I.E:

 `zcat /var/log/nginx/access.log.*.gz | goaccess`**`-`**`/var/log/nginx/access.log --log-format=COMBINED`

Problem solved! I changed the permissions on the log file.
Many thanks!

title: Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
body:
Hi,

I am unable to make goaccess works on CentOS release 6.8 running Apache/2.2.15 

cat /var/log/httpd/ssl_access_log
```
192.168.1.10 - username [21/Oct/2020:16:51:25 -0300] "GET /top.html HTTP/1.1" 200 2003
192.168.1.11 - - [21/Oct/2020:17:20:47 -0300] "GET /BGP HTTP/1.1" 401 478
```

cat /etc/goaccess.conf
```
time-format %H:%M:%S
date-format %d/%b/%Y
log-format %h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b
```

goaccess syntax
```
name@server$ goaccess /var/log/httpd/ssl_access_log -o /usr/local/report.html --log-format=COMBINED
/var/log/httpd/ssl_access_log
Parsed 10 lines producing the following errors:

Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.
Token for '%b' specifier is NULL.

Format Errors - Verify your log/date/time format

name@server$
```

I have tried to remove %b from log-format %h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b, but problem remain

Any idea is more than welcome.
author: zetto33

comments.body:
nevermind.. I was using wrong syntax... 

I have edited file /etc/goaccess.conf , but I still was using '--log-format=COMBINED'. Using correct syntax it start working
name@server$ goaccess /var/log/httpd/ssl_access_log -o /usr/local/report.html
Glad that worked!

title: Custom log format
author: route-print

comments.body:
This should do it:

    goaccess access.log --log-format='~h{", } %v %^ %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b %D "%R" "%u"' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T
Thanks!, that did the trick.

I'm trying to process 1 month of Cloudfront logs (120GB) to html or csv and the process OOMs at around 61 million records.

built from source ( ./configure --enable-utf8 )
running with the following: goaccess jan.log --log-format=CLOUDFRONT -o cdn-jan.csv --restore --persist --db-path /root/persist

any ideas how to best solve this?
@packeteer how much ram/swap do you have available? also, do you have a lot of timestamped or unique requests? if that's the case, you could try using `-q`.

author: XfactorDO

comments.body:
`--log-format='%h %v %d %t %U %s %u %b %T %^'`

Should help

Try this, in `goaccess.conf`:

`time-format %H:%M:%S` or in same way `time-format %T`
`date-format %Y-%m-%d` or in same way `date-format %F`
`log-format %h %^ %d %t %U %s %u %b %L %^`

or in command-line
`--time-format='...' --date-format='...' --log-format='...'`

**notes:**
I believe that `.00` and `.000` in the `IPs` are just examples. These values are not valid.
There is no field for the `http method`, so use `--http-method=no`.

It will be difficult to process this `LOG`. 
It sometimes introduces the `user-agent`, others not present.
You will must have to separate these lines into 2 distinct files.
Or ignore all fields just after status `%s`, using `%^`. i.e. : 

`log-format %h %^ %d %t %U %s %^`
Closing this. Feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: goaccess conf for fail2ban logs ?
body:
Hello everyone,

I'm a bit stuck on the way to **configure goaccess to read the fail2ban logs** that have this format/syntax : 

`2020-08-13 18:57:11,326 fail2ban.actions        [10357]: NOTICE  [firewall] Ban ww.xx.yy.zz`

Can't figure out the log-format (tried various combinations related to `%d %t %^ %^ %^ %^ %^ %h` syntax).

Could you help :) ? 

Thanks in advance.

Sincerely,
author: securixhk

comments.body:
The solution is to carefully respect the `spaces` quantity :) besides some tricks as : 

18:57:11,326 -> **%t,%^**

Thanks

You can try:
 
    goaccess fail2ban.log --log-format='%d %t,%^ %U %^ %^ %^ %v %h' --date-format=%Y-%m-%d --time-format=%T --http-protocol=no --http-method=no --ignore-panel=OS --ignore-panel=BROWSERS
Closing this, feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: Error occured at src/parser.c - read_log. But only when run from cron. And yes, I'm using absolute paths.
body:
Hi,
I know this looks like the 50 identical issues I've googled so far, but I have no idea why this doesn't work. The point is, it works when invoked in shell, but doesn't when run from cron. The cron is root-owned, so there should be no permission issues. I use absolute paths, so ENV variables shouldn't be an issue either.

This is the problematic line:
```
zcat /var/log/nginx/access.log.*.gz | goaccess /var/log/nginx/access.log{,.1} - -q --log-format=COMBINED -o /var/www/html/foo/bar/report.html >/dev/null
```

It works in shell, but not in cron.

```
Parsing... [0] [0/s]
GoAccess - version 1.2 - Jun 19 2017 12:55:29
Config file: /etc/goaccess.conf

Fatal error has occurred
Error occured at: src/parser.c - read_log - 2669
Unable to open the specified log file. No such file or directory
```

This looks like I misspecified the log paths, but when I paste the command into shell, everything works. I thought it was going to be `$PATH` issue, but I specify absolute paths everywhere. And both `zcat` and `goaccess` are in cron `$PATH` already.

Any ideas?
author: SoptikHa2

comments.body:
Can you please try without expanding multiple logs?

    zcat /var/log/nginx/access.log.*.gz | goaccess /var/log/nginx/access.log - -q --log-format=COMBINED -o /var/www/html/foo/bar/report.html

and  

     goaccess /var/log/nginx/access.log - -q --log-format=COMBINED -o /var/www/html/foo/bar/report.html

Thanks a lot, the issue disappears when I remove the shell expand. I guess it's some shell opt-in feature.

Sorry for inconvenience!

Glad that solved the issue. Yeah my best guess is that the cron doesn't expand it due to a tty. You can probably run a scripts instead of running goaccess directly.

Closing this. Feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: Help with custom log format with tabs
body:
Hi, I have a custom log that separates data by tab (TSV log format).
Log is a DNS query.

This is a snipped of the log
[2020-05-27 14:47:47]	10.10.1.1	badexample.com	A	FORWARD	24ms	10.10.1.1:53

This is my goaccess.conf 

```
time-format %H:%M:%S
date-format %Y-%m-%d
log-format [%d %t] %h %v %U %^ %^ %^ %^

```
It works fine when I manually change tab to space, but can't figure out how to get the tab read by goaccess so interprets the log file.

This is what I keep getting when trying to run goaccess

Parsed 1 lines producing the following errors:
Token for '%h' specifier is NULL.
Format Errors - Verify your log/date/time format

Thanks in advance
author: p01acos

comments.body:
You can always use `\t` as delimiter. e.g., 

    log-format [%d %t]\t%h\t%v\t%U\t%^

> log-format [%d %t]\t%h\t%v\t%U\t%^

so simple yet so far :|
bloody legend mate, cheers

title: Token '92.118.161.13.netsystemsresearch.com' doesn't match specifier '%h' in v1.4
body:
Using Apache  common log format. When running goaccess (v1.4):
/usr/local/bin/goaccess - -o /home/cvmiller/my_report.html --log-format=COMBINED

I get the error:
```
Parsed 1 lines producing the following errors:

Token '92.118.161.13.netsystemsresearch.com' doesn't match specifier '%h'

Format Errors - Verify your log/date/time format
```

It seems like the parser is confused by the fact that the hostname begins like an IPv4 address, but is in fact part of a larger hostname. Other hosts which fail with this error are:
```
187.114.156.0.static.host.gvt.net.br
ec2-34-223-93-168.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com
```
Also saw this issue  in version 1.3. Built goaccess with the following:
```
 ./configure --enable-utf8 --without-libintl-prefix
make
sudo make install
```
author: cvmiller

comments.body: You can try using `--no-ip-validation`.

Thanks! That solves the problem.

Perhaps this is a documentation issue, as I don't see `--no-ip-validation` in the `--help`

Thanks for reporting that. I did add it to the man page but completely forgot adding it to the `--help`. I just pushed an update upstream.

Closing this, feel free to reopen it if needed.

./configure --enable-debug --enable-geoip=mmdb --enable-utf8 --with-getline --with-openssl

persist true
restore true
geoip-database /usr/share/GeoIP/GeoLite2-City.mmdb

title: Counts hits etc multiple times if log configured in .conf & command line
body:
I've only been using Goaccess for a few days and love it but was surprised to see my web traffic almost doubled over a period of one hour.

I'm using version 1.3 on  Centos 7.

I checked the stats in the usual way and then closed it. Came back an hour later and reloaded it and found web traffic had doubled. The difference being that I had configured the goaccess.conf and included the log file to read and then loaded from the command line using "sudo goaccess /var/log/nginx/access.log"

It would seem goaccess read /var/log/nginx/access.log from the config file and then again from the command line and processed it twice.

Is it possible to add an internal check to see if the log file has been re-specified? I'm likely to do it again and be just as confused as I was earlier.
author: Admiral-Noisy-Bottom

comments.body: I'm guessing you are using the on-disk storage? If that's the case, the soon-to-be-release version will have this protection. #334

Brilliant, thanks. It isn't a real issue but it was confusing until I realized my mistake.

Thanks again.

OK I checked the git log and I found there's new option named `--keep-last=<NUM>`

If I am correct, I should use `--keep-last=<NUM> --persist --restore`.
There are three options. `--persist` `--restore` `--db-path=<dir>` by default it saves all data to /tmp

BTW, `--keep-last` it's used to only show the last x number of days. e.g., show last 5 days and regardless of how many days it parsed. It does clean up the data that's not within those X days if new data is appended.

title: How to analyze zipped log files on a remote webserver?
body:
I want to set up goaccess on my local RaspberryPi and after that I want to analyze logfiles from a few remote server of the same provider. This provider stores all the logfiles in /logs

So far so good...

But... all these logfiles are zipped like: access_log_2020-03-03.gz
Is it somehow possible to read these zipped logfiles with goaccess?

Thanks in advance... :)
author: JoshDebris

comments.body: Great question. I'd use `sshfs` and mount that directory on your RaspberryPi.

Thank you for that tip.

I'm totaly overwhelmed wth the whole Linux stuff.... but I will read the documentation about sshfs.
Hopefully I can get goaccess running at all? ;-)

You should be able to run it as (assuming debian on the RaspberryPi):

```
  # apt-get install sshfs
  # mkdir /home/your_user/logs
  # sshfs remote_user@remote_server.com:/var/log/apache2/ /home/your_user/logs
  # zcat -f /home/your_user/logs/access.log* | goaccess - --log-format=COMBINED
```

I use `socat` for transfer and real-time analysis.
However, you will need to have a permanent link and some mechanism/trick to deal with any failure.

You could try:

    # ssh -n root@server 'zcat -f /var/log/apache2/access_log*' | goaccess -

**Note**: SSH requires `-n` so GoAccess can read from stdin. Also, make sure to use SSH keys for authentication as it won't work if a passphrase is required.

title: Tomcat 8.5.47 COMBINED
body:
Hi, I use lastest release:
```
$ goaccess --version
GoAccess - 1.3.
```

I have set up server.xml as

```
<Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.AccessLogValve" directory="logs"
          prefix="api-example_access_log" suffix=".txt"
          pattern="combined" />
```

than after restart new file generated logs like:

> 127.0.0.1 - - [13/Feb/2020:23:29:49 +0100] "GET / HTTP/1.1" 302 - "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:72.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/72.0"
> 127.0.0.1 - - [13/Feb/2020:23:29:50 +0100] "GET /login/auth HTTP/1.1" 200 2283 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:72.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/72.0"
> 127.0.0.1 - - [13/Feb/2020:23:29:50 +0100] "GET /favicon.ico HTTP/1.1" 404 46 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:72.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/72.0"
> 

### COMBINED 
 after running
`$ goaccess ./logs/api-example_access_log.2020-02-13.txt --log-format=COMBINED`

I received:

>  Parsing... [0] [0/s]                                                                                                                                             /./logs/api-example_access_log.2020-02-13.txt
> Parsed 1 linesproducing the following errors:
> 
> Token '13/Feb/2020' doesn't match specifier '%d'
> 
> Format Errors - Verify your log/date/time format

same error pops up if I start goaccess without `--log-format` param and choose `NCSA Combined Log Format `

same issue if I run 
`$ LANG="en_US.UTF-8" bash -c 'goaccess ./logs/api-example_access_log.2020-02-13.txt --log-format=COMBINED'`

###  VCOMBINED

 after running
`$ goaccess ./logs/api-example_access_log.2020-02-13.txt --log-format=VCOMBINED`

I received:

>  Parsing... [0] [0/s]                                                                                                                                             /./logs/api-example_access_log.2020-02-13.txt
> Parsed 1 linesproducing the following errors:
> 
> Token '+0100]' doesn't match specifier '%h'
> 
> Format Errors - Verify your log/date/time format

sam eissue if I run 
`LANG="en_US.UTF-8" bash -c 'goaccess ./logs/api-example_access_log.2020-02-13.txt --log-format=VCOMBINED'`

```
$ uname -a
FreeBSD example.com 11.3-RELEASE-p3 FreeBSD 11.3-RELEASE-p3 #1: Tue Oct 15 01:53:29 CEST 2019
```

Any help will be appreciated
author: majkelo

comments.body:
### Solution

`LC_ALL="en_US.UTF-8" bash -c 'goaccess ./logs/api-example_access_log.2020-02-13.txt --log-format=COMBINED'`

### Explanation

my system has different locale:

```
$ locale
LANG=
LC_CTYPE=pl_PL.UTF-8
LC_COLLATE=pl_PL.UTF-8
LC_TIME=pl_PL.UTF-8
LC_NUMERIC=pl_PL.UTF-8
LC_MONETARY=pl_PL.UTF-8
LC_MESSAGES=pl_PL.UTF-8
LC_ALL=
```
I had to explicitly enforce US locale (for alphabetic name of the month)
Good call on that. Probably a better error message should be displayed on those cases.

title: Parsing access log date and time in a single variable tab delimited
body:
Hi all, I'm new to goaccess and I'm trying to my web access log to be inspect:

this is my apache log format: 

`LogFormat "%V\t%h\t%{SSL_PROTOCOL}x\t%{SSL_CIPHER}x\t%{SSL_CLIENT_S_DN_CN}x\t%u\t%{%d/%m/%Y %T %Z}t\t%{UNIQUE_ID}e\t%{JSESSIONID}C\t%H\t%m\t%U\t\"%q\"\t%>s\t%b\t\"%{Referer}i\"\t\"%{User-Agent}i\"\t%D\t%X\t%I\t%O" mycustumlog
`


example output:


    www.test.it   192.168.253.176                 -       -       20/01/2020 01:00:47 CET XiTtr38AAAEAAAzn8PkAAABX        7E7E5A44F91C8095E2E6EC57EBD0221E        HTTP/1.1        GET     0       /cms/   ""      200     143296  "-"     "Zabbix"        309722  +       477     147885

`
I try with:

`goaccess access.log -o report.html  -p /etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf  --time-format='%H:%M:%S %Z' --date-format='%d/%m/%Y' --log-format='%v\t%h\t-\t-\t-\t%d\t'`

but I get:

```
Parsed 1 linesproducing the following errors:

Token '20/01/2020 01:00:47 CET' doesn't match specifier '%d'

Format Errors - Verify your log/date/time format

```
Could anyone help?
author: ghost

comments.body:
For this log:

```
www.test.it	192.168.253.176	-	-	20/01/2020 01:00:47 CET	XiTtr38AAAEAAAzn8PkAAABX	7E7E5A44F91C8095E2E6EC57EBD0221E	HTTP/1.1	GET	0	/cms/	""	200	143296	"-"	"Zabbix"	309722	+	477	147885
```

This should work:

    goaccess access.log --log-format='%v\t%h\t%^\t%^\t%d %t %^\t%^\t%^\t%H\t%m\t%^\t%U\t"%q"\t%%s\t%b\t^"%R"\r"%u"\t%D\t%^' --date-format=%d/%m/%Y --time-format=%T

thank you so much! I add some extra %^ to parse "-" chars and now the magic string:

     goaccess access.log --log-format='%v\t%h\t%^\t%^\t%^\t%^\t%d %t %^\t%^\t%^\t%H\t%m\t%^\t%U\t"%q"\t%%s\t%b\t^"%R"\r"%u"\t%D\t%^' --date-format=%d/%m/%Y --time-format=%T

thanks for help! Great software!!!
Glad that did the job :)

comments.body: Please post some lines from your access log.

Hello.

Same error message here.

This is my log line:

`"192.168.56.1, 172.19.1.10, 127.0.0.81" 127.0.0.1 - - [30/Jul/2020:09:02:39 +0100] "GET / HTTP/1.1" 302 901 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/84.0.4147.105 Safari/537.36" "-" 109488`

And parsing command:

`goaccess /var/log/apache2/www.access.log --time-format='%H:%M:%S' --date-format='%d/%b/%Y' -a --all-static-files --keep-last=30 --persist -o /tmp/a.html --log-format='~h{," } %^ - %e %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u" %^ %L'`

Apart from the fact that it is not too clear if the '%d' token mentioned in the error message stands for date or for day, I have the following questions:
- in the default config log formats, I see that the square brackets are preceded by '%^'. What is correct to match (and skip parsing) a left bracket: is it '%^[' or simply '[' ?
- same for a literal '-' in the log
- and how to match (and skip) the token '"something"', ie. wrapped in double quotes?
- what is the correct time format that would match the timezone after the space, is it: '%H:%M:%S %z'?

Answering to my own question(s):

1. it seems that the correct formats in my case are:

```
time-format='%H:%M:%S %z'
log-format='~h{ ",} %^[%d:%t] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u" "%^" %L'
```

2. it seems that a single '%^' token does greedy matching, ie. it will match any chars, including whitespace (but probably not a double quote nor slash character). That's why '%^[' can be used to match the string '127.0.0.1 - - ['

It would be nice if the parsing tokens were better explained in the docs and default config file.

Also: it would be nice to have a token able to match any length of non-whitespace chars - it would make life easier when matching multiple non-quoted fields...

And while I am at it: it could also help troubleshooting if, when a parsing error is found, the program would echo the current-line matched value for each token up to the offending one, eg. in my case the matched value for '~h{ ",}', then the matched value for '%^', etc...

@gggeek Thanks for the feedback. I can look into those suggestions.

Can you please post a few lines from your access log so I can take a look at what might be the issue? Thanks again.

Hello. Thanks for replying.

I have pasted in my first comment an example of what my log lines look like, as well as a correct log-format string in the 2nd comment (now reformatted for readability).

I did not keep a copy of the log-format strings which I tested unsuccessfully before managing to build the correct one, however I can tell by memory that I struggled with:

- parsing the bit `  127.0.0.1 - - [ ` : I tried to use 3 tokens for that, unsuccessfully. I settled on using a single `%^` to match and discard it all even though at least the 2nd dash might actually be used by goaccess when it is not a dash but a username (we do use basic auth for some parts of the site)

- understanding what is matched by `%^`

- understanding how to match bits like `-` and `"hello"`

Looks like your access log has english dates while your system locale is set to Chinese. 

    LANG="en_US.UTF-8" bash -c 'goaccess access.log --log-format=COMBINED'

comments.body:
GoAccess requires the following fields:

> a valid IPv4/6 %h
> a valid date %d
> the request %r

@allinurl 
What is the minimum log format in Nginx?
Not sure. I'm guessing only one field?

@allinurl 
My bad, I meant for goaccess

my current log format as you saw is 
```
log_format  main_ext  '$remote_addr - "$http_user_agent"';
```

as i'm only interested in logging IP's, OS and Browsers.

What else should I add as a minimum so that goaccess would accept my log file ? or anyway i could bypass that?

@allinurl 

As per your guideline, this is my log format now
```
    log_format  main_ext  '$remote_addr - $remote_user [$time_local]'
                          '"$request" "$http_user_agent"' ;
```

and when i start goaccess i use this command
```
goaccess -f /var/log/nginx/site-access.*
```

Then I choose `NCSA Combined Log Format` and then I delete ` %s %b "%R"` from log format

My question is how can I append this to my command?

**I found the solution and its working great !!**
I just need you to confirm if it's right

```
goaccess -f /var/log/nginx/site-access.* --log-format="%h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" "%u"" --date-format="%d/%b/%Y" --time-format="%H:%M:%S"
```
Glad you got it work. That looks right to me for the minimum amount of data.

just one last question, how to add several panels in `--ignore-panel` ?

```
REQUESTS_STATIC NOT_FOUND VISIT_TIMES REFERRERS REFERRING_SITES KEYPHRASES STATUS_CODES
```
--ignore-panel=REQUESTS_STATIC --ignore-panel=NOT_FOUND --ignore-panel=VISIT_TIMES --ignore-panel=REFERRERS --ignore-panel=REFERRING_SITES --ignore-panel=KEYPHRASES --ignore-panel=STATUS_CODES
or if you prefer & cleaner, through the config file.

@allinurl 
 
Well, I will stick with this now. Thank you very much for your time :)

title: GoAccess submitting aggregate data to MySQL
body: Is it possible to make GoAccess count views from Apache log (single server) in real-time and submit the aggregate data to MySQL according some threshold? (ex: each 5 min or 1KB)
author: MarkMessa

comments.body: It's not possible. Could you please describe a use case for this? Thanks.

> Could you please describe a use case for this?

Suppose you wanna count views and update MySQL aggregate table out of the client request cycle.  
It seems that the most common way to achieve that is via ELK stack. Unfortunately, for a single server, ELK stack is to much complicated. Therefore, I'm looking for lighter alternatives.

I'm working on a more robust on-disk storage which more likely will support wither postgres or mysql. This will replace the existing on-disk implementation. Please stay tuned for the upcoming release.

@allinurl Mind to give more details?
- Is this gonna be an improvement of GoAccess or it will be a completely new web analytics software?
- Still FOSS?
- Still lightweight?
It's just a change on the current on-disk implementation. Always FOSS, and lightweight too.
Any release date forecast?

That would be a really nice to have.
A changeable DSN like mysql://user@pasword:server/database insteat of slite3://path/to/folder

I was reading how you had added the ability to add a list of browsers in a text file, and was trying to use this as a way to omit our uptime requests from the log parsing.

We use NodePing, so i created a file called browsers.txt, using your demo file and added a line to the top:
NodePing                                          Crawler

I was using the following command in bash:

    bash-4.4$ goaccess /cygdrive/e/temp/goaxess/*.log --log-format='%d %t.%^ ~h{," } %e %v %^ %m %U %q %s %^ %^ %L "%u" %R %^' --date-format=%Y-%m-%d --time-format=%T --http-protocol=no -o /cygdrive/e/temp/ws_all_report_20190919.html --real-time-html --browsers-file=/cygdrive/e/temp/browsers.txt --ignore-crawlers

It still has the same mount of requests over all with or without the last two switches in the command line (I think this is intended to show the total number of requests without filtering the browsers file)

I am just looking for confirmation that this is the way to execute this type of result

Let me know what you think

comments.body:
Please try setting it as `Crawlers` instead of `Crawler`. Also make sure it is tab delimited e.g.,

    NodePing\t\tCrawlers

that is, 

    NodePing		Crawlers

I added the tab delimiter in between the name and the type instead of spaces.

I also see that it removes the top requested file based on the browsers.txt file.

This is what i was looking for 

Thanks!

log_format upstreamlog '[$time_local] $remote_addr -> $upstream_addr | $scheme $request | urt: $upstream_response_time msec | rt: $request_time msec | status: $status';

title: SSL problem
body:
Hi guys,

I have installed goaccess but i want to use it with SSL.

So far i have installed with --with-openssl and i have this input line 

`find /home/ubuntu/s3/ -cmin -300 -name "*.log" -exec cat {} \; | goaccess -a - --log-format=AWSELB -p /usr/local/etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf -o /var/www/html/index.html --ssl-cert=/home/ubuntu/s3/server.crt --ssl-key=/home/ubuntu/s3/server.key --ws-url=wss://publicipoftheserver:7890`

Then when i visit my public ip i don't have ssl, even with :7890 and with https:// i only have port 80, and goaccess doesn't show any errors while parsing. Tried to use debug mode but no luck there.
Only working option is without ssl, port 80, is there anything else i need to look for ?
I am using Ubuntu 16.04.

Thanks guys.
author: kenzoawa

comments.body:
The reason for the ws-url is for live updating. 
So 1. Enable that with â€”real-time-html
2. You can probably skip the ws-url if the websocket will be on the same host as goaccess (very likely).
Now check it. Note that if you DONâ€™T want the live updates, then thereâ€™s no websocket on port 7890 and you can also skip the SSL flags. The static page is served by your existing ssl-configured web server, using its ports. There is a nonzero chance I am wrong about some of this, but this ended up working for me. Oh and obviously, check any firewalls too.
So basically you are saying that i just insert the SSL certs and keys to the apache that is running local and skip the SSL flags .. etc right ?

Correct. The report page itself is a plain old static page served by Apache, and if you have configured Apache for SSL, then the report page will be delivered as such. You only need to explicitly tell goaccess about SSL and certificates if you want the real time HTML data that is transferred between the goaccess websocket and the end-userâ€™s browser to be encrypted. Thatâ€™s when you specify the cert and the key to goaccess, and if necessary the ws server and port. The latter will default to your apache host, and port 7890.
Strangely, I found that using the ws=wss directive to specify the server and port caused the real time HTML to not work, whereas not specifying that and letting the defaults be used did work, even though what I was specifying were in fact the defaults. 


â€”
Sent from a mouse-sized keyboard, please forgve typos.

> On Apr 24, 2019, at 8:23 AM, kenzoawa <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> So basically you are saying that i just insert the SSL certs and keys to the apache that is running local and skip the SSL flags .. etc right ?
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

Hey @iWoodsman thanks for the advice, much appreciated! I was successful.   

I have installed the SSL on the apache and works like a charm if you are not using --real-time-html.

If anyone stumbles across that problem - just use ssl on the apache without real time report.

title: syncing logs from elb - live report
body:
Hey guys, i just tried GoAccess and it works like a charm once you get to know it.

It's not a issue but more of a logical question.

I am successful in parsing the s3/elb logs that are stored there with s3cmd sync command to EC2. 
What i am trying to do is having that sync from s3 to GoAccess live - incrementally because sync works that way, only new logs are shipped and i want those new ones added to the report, not all of them.

If i put the command for report.html it parses the whole folder, not just the new ones that were copied. 
Here is the command : 

`find /tmp/s3/ -name "*.log" -exec cat {} \; | goaccess -a --log-format=AWSELB -p /usr/local/etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf -o /var/www/html/report.html --real-time-html`

Is there any possibility for goaccess to only parse the new logs in real time because my bucket is dozens of gigabytes ? I tried something with crontab but unsuccessful. 
Thank you guys.
author: kenzoawa

comments.body:
You could use find and see the latest mod files:

> find . -cmin +<time>
> find . -cmin -<time>
> find . -cmin  <time>

For example, the files with last edition in a maximum of 5 minutes, are given by:

    find  /tmp/s3/ -cmin -5 -name "*.log" -exec cat {} \; | goaccess -a --log-format=AWSELB -p /usr/local/etc/goaccess/goaccess.conf -o /var/www/html/report.html --real-time-html

Thank you very much allinurl! 
You are a saver. 

I will try the command and give feedback here.
Works like a charm, thanks allinurl!

title: --keep-db-files not available
body: When I want to use --keep-db-files command, it prompts me that it does not exist. When I recompile configure: error:*** Missing development libraries for Tokyo Cabinet Database./configure --enable-utf8 --enable-geoip=legacy --enable-tcb=btree.But when I do./configure --enable-utf8 --enable-geoip=legacy --enable-tcb, it works. Will the btree open
author: orange723

comments.body: Storage method: in-memory Hash Database (Default) is displayed as follows after successful compilation
That's right. If `btree` or `memhash` is not specified, it defaults to the main hash tables.

> That's right. If `btree` or `memhash` is not specified, it defaults to the main hash tables.

I want to use --keep-db-files this parameter how should I compile --keep-db-files is based on btree

This should enable `--keep-db-files` and `--load-from-disk`:

    $ ./configure --enable-utf8 --enable-geoip=legacy --enable-tcb=btree
    $ make
    # make install

or to uninstall

    # make uninstall

> This should enable `--keep-db-files` and `--load-from-disk`:
> 
> ```
> $ ./configure --enable-utf8 --enable-geoip=legacy --enable-tcb=btree
> $ make
> # make install
> ```
> or to uninstall
> 
> ```
> # make uninstall
> ```
Configure: error: *** Missing development libraries for Tokyo Cabinet Database

Please try:

    # apt-get install libtokyocabinet-dev

> Please try:
> 
> ```
> # apt-get install libtokyocabinet-dev
> ```

I'm sorry to reply you so late. I can't find it using yum search using centos7 system

I think I've found a solution. Thank you very much 
yum install tokyocabinet-devel ncurses-devel geoip-devel bzip2-devel
./configure --enable-utf8 --enable-geoip=legacy --enable-tcb=btree
Glad to hear that :+1:  Feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: How to use Chinese with GoAccess?
body: Helloï¼Œeveryoneï¼Œ i want make out to use chinese, but i don't want to change LANG. Have any method to realize this?
author: damaainan

comments.body:
Like this
```
export LANG="zh_CN.UTF-8"      
goaccess -a -d -f access.log -p goaccess.conf -o report_all.html  
export LANG="en_US.UTF-8"     
````
You have to set `LANG` as it relies on `gettext` to perform the translations.

You could try something like:

    LANG="zh_CN.UTF-8" bash -c 'goaccess access.log --log-format=COMBINED'

> You could try something like:

> ```
> LANG="zh_CN.UTF-8" bash -c 'goaccess access.log --log-format=COMBINED'
> ```

title: custom log format / additional identifiers
body:
i'm trying to make goaccess understand my custom log format. basically it's standard apache, but extended by some fields. i've read parser.c to build my own format, but failed to find the following identifiers:


```
 127.0.0.1- - [01/Nov/2018:07:48:51 +0000] "GET / HTTP/1.1" 302 120 "-" "Mozilla/5.0" 616 6347 mod_deflate: In:124 Out:102:82pct 62485 0 - localhost
<---------------- A P A C H E  F O R M A T ----------------------------------------->  %I  %O  mod_deflate: In:%IC Out:%OC:%Cpct   %D %k %s   %v
```
%I received bytes (total)
%O sent bytes (total)
%IC compression input bytes
%OC compresseion output bytes
%C compression ratio
%k keepalive requests
%s status 

here's the apache log format config:
```
LogFormat "%h %l %u %t \"%r\" %>s %b \"%{Referer}i\" \"%{User-Agent}i\" %I %O mod_deflate: In:%{deflate_in_info}n Out:%{deflate_out_info}n:%{deflate_ratio_info}npct %D %k %X %V"
```

in general it would be useful to have a "ignore"-identifier, so that we can parse logs, even though some fields are not implemented.
author: pille

comments.body:
Please try the following:

    goaccess access.log --log-format='%h %^[%d:%t %^] "%r" %s %b "%R" "%u" %^ %^ %^ %^ %^ %D %^' --date-format=%d/%b/%Y --time-format=%T

thanks. `%^` was the field i was missing. 
feel free to close if you don't plan on implementing compression ratio report.
